text: Creates a single DOP object from SOP Geometry that represents a number of RBD Objects.

The RBD Packed Object DOP creates a single DOP Object inside the DOP simulation.
It takes the geometry from the given SOP Path and uses each primitive that has a transform and a single point to represent an RBD object. This includes primitives such as

, spheres, and tubes.
Each primitive provides the collision geometry for a rigid body, and attributes on the primitive’s point are used to store information such as orientation, mass, and velocity.
The resulting DOP Object represents large numbers of objects in a more efficient manner than the

.
This object representation is currently only understood by the
In Houdini 13, RBD Packed Objects can’t interact with other solvers such as cloth and fluids.

uses several point attributes to
store the properties of each piece of a packed object.
Specifies whether the object is able to react to other objects in the simulation. The default active state is set by the
The age of the object, in seconds.
Specifies whether the object’s transform should be updated from its SOP geometry at each timestep. This attribute is only used if the
attribute is set to 0. The default value is set by the

The elasticity of the object. If two objects of bounce 1.0 collide, they will rebound without losing energy. If two objects of bounce 0.0 collide, they will come to a standstill. The default value is set by the
When enabled, any impacts that occur during the simulation will be recorded in the
data. Enabling this option may cause the simulation time and memory usage to increase.
The sleeping threshold for the object’s angular velocity. If the object’s angular speed is below this threshold for a period of time, the object may be treated as non-moving.
Specifies whether the object should be completely ignored by the Bullet solver. Unlike setting the
attribute to zero, other objects in the simulation will not be able to collide against this object.
The sleeping threshold for the object’s linear velocity. If the object’s linear speed is below this threshold for a period of time, the object may be treated as non-moving.
Disables simulation of a non-moving object until the object moves again. The linear and angular speed thresholds are used to determine whether the object is non-moving. If the
checkbox is turned off, you will see the color of the Guide Geometry change from the

Specifies whether the mass of the object should be computed automatically from the object’s collision shape and density. The default value is set by the
Stores the simulation time at which the object was created.
Specifies whether the object should be deleted during the next solve. The
node can be used to generate this attribute.
Specifies whether the object’s collision shape should be rebuilt from its SOP geometry at each timestep. The default value is set by the
The mass of an object is its volume times its density. The default value is set by the
The coefficient of friction of the object. A value of 0 means the object is frictionless. The default value is set by the
A scale factor that is applied to the inertial tensor of the object. A higher stiffness will make the object less likely to spin. The default value is set by the

The maximum age of the object, in seconds. When the
attribute exceeds this value, the object will be marked dead.
The mass of the object. If

(the transform applied by the simulation). The position transform is defined by

attribute if it exists.
            When adjusting this attribute, it is not required to update the packed primitive’s transform as it will be updated by the Bullet solver at the end of the timestep.
The solver automatically updates the collision geometry and the object’s inertial tensor to reflect this scale.
To recompute the object’s mass when the scale is changed, set the

The linear velocity of the object. The initial velocity is set by the
The angular velocity of the object, in radians per second. The initial angular velocity is set by the
The following attributes can be used to customize the collision shape for each object.
Shrinks the collision geometry to prevent the

from increasing the effective size of the object.
            This can improve the simulation’s performance by preventing initially closely-packed collision shapes from interpenetrating, and also removes the gap between objects caused by the
Specifies whether to use the bounds of the object’s geometry to compute the collision shape when

A padding distance between shapes, which is used by the Bullet engine to improve the reliability and performance of the collision detection. You may need to scale this value depending on the scale of your scene. This padding increases the size of the collision shape, so it is recommended to enable

to prevent the collision shape from growing.
            This option is not supported for the
Specifies the color of the shape’s guide geometry.
Specifies the color of the shape’s guide geometry if the object is not moving and has been deactivated by the solver.

The collision shape used to represent the object.

The attributes listed below can be used to configure the object’s collision-related behavior.
If the object is inactive and has a positive

value, it will not be activated by
            collisions with any objects that match this pattern. The pattern
            uses the same syntax as the
For an agent, specifies which of its rigid bodies should be activated when using the

attribute.
            The default behavior is to activate all of the agent’s rigid bodies.
            This attribute is expected to contain the name of a
that specifies which joints' rigid bodies should be activated.

Specifies the name of a collision group that this object belongs
            to. This can be used by the

attribute to ignore
            collisions against specific groups of objects.

The object will not collide against any objects that match this pattern.
            This pattern can use the name of DOP objects, the ID of DOP objects, DOP groups, the
point attribute of a packed primitive in an

point attribute values of an agent primitive.
            The
node can be used to generate this attribute.
will disable all collisions, and an empty string will enable all collisions.

will disable collisions against packed primitives whose
(or DOP objects whose name begins with

The minimum impulse from a collision that will cause the object to switch from inactive to active. The activation occurs at the instant that the collision occurs.
            The
attribute can be used to prevent the object from being activated by collisions with particular objects.

Sticky collisions will not occur for collisions with any objects that match this pattern.
            The pattern uses the same syntax as the

The minimum impulse from a collision that will cause the object to stick to the other object.
            The constraint between the two objects is created at the instant that the collision occurs.
            The
attribute can be used to prevent the object from being stuck to particular objects.

The maximum number of other objects that this object can be stuck to.
            A value less than or equal to 0 disables this behavior, allowing the object to be stuck to any number of other objects.
Updated by the solver to track the number of other objects that this object was stuck to (limited by

).
            This can be used to easily determine whether sticky collisions have occurred for an object, without having to inspect the constraint network geometry.

The maximum number of anchor points (constraints) that can be used to stick this object to another object.
            Constraints are attached at contact points between the two objects.
            The default value is 1, allowing a single constraint to be created between each pair of objects.

The attributes listed below can be used to clamp the linear or angular speed of specific objects.
The clamping is performed during each substep after forces and constraints have been applied (but before positions are updated), so this enforces a hard limit on the object’s speed.
If the attribute value is negative, no clamping is performed.
For animated or deforming static objects, the speed limit affects the velocities used when resolving collisions.
The
node can be used to generate these attributes.
The slowest speed (in units/second) that an object can move. This does not affect stationary objects.
The fastest speed (in units/second) that an object can move.
The slowest speed (in radians/second) that an object can rotate. This does not affect non-spinning objects.
The fastest speed (in radians/second) that an object can rotate.
The attributes listed below can be used to limit the

in the object’s linear or angular velocity when solving constraints and collisions.
This does not affect changes to the object’s velocity due to external forces, and is enforced each frame after constraints have been solved and positions have been updated.
This can be useful to tame collisions that produce very high linear or angular velocities.
If the value is negative, no clamping is performed.
For best results, it is recommended to clamp both linear and angular acceleration simultaneously.

Setting the max acceleration to a very low value can introduce jitter for situations such as objects resting on the ground plane.
    With such values, the contact constraints cannot change the object’s velocity by enough to counter the acceleration due to gravity.
Limits the change in the object’s speed that is caused by enforcing constraints.
Limits the change in the object’s angular speed that is caused by enforcing constraints.
The attributes listed below can be used to apply forces to specific objects. Nodes such as
can be used to generate these forces.
Specifies how important it is to match the target velocity (
When an object is dragged by the
attributes, this attribute is used to further scale the drag amount.
Higher drag exponents cause objects that are far from
to recover faster than those that are already close to the target velocity.
Specifies a force that will be applied to the center of mass of the object.
Specifies how important it is to match the target angular velocity (
Specifies a target velocity for the object. This is used in combination with the
attribute to compute a force that will move the object towards the desired velocity.
Specifies a target angular velocity for the object. This is used in combination with the
attribute to compute a torque that will move the object towards the desired angular velocity.
Specifies a torque that will be applied to the object.

For agent primitives, a rigid body is created for each transform in its rig that has at least one shape attached to it in the agent’s collision layer.
Array attributes are used for properties that can vary for each of an agent’s rigid bodies, and the attributes are named with the

suffix.
The arrays are indexed using the transform index from the agent’s rig.
The following array attributes are required:
The following array attributes are optional and can be used instead of the regular point attributes if varying values are needed.
The attributes listed below can also be used for agent primitives.
Specifies whether the solver should update the agent’s overall transform (e.g. the

point attributes) based on the root rigid body’s motion.
            This option is useful for a full ragdoll so that the agent’s point follows its motion, but may cause issues for a partial ragdoll where the agent’s overall transform is already being updated elsewhere (e.g. by the
Below is a list of attributes that are maintained internally by the solver. You should not modify these attributes yourself.
is enabled, this value stores whether the solver has already computed collision shape attributes such as

Tracks whether the object has been put to sleep by the solver.
            This occurs after the object and any nearby / constrained objects have been below the
When manually waking an object, the
attribute should also be set to zero so that the object isn’t immediately put back to sleep.
The amount of time that the object’s speed has been below the
. The solver uses this value to disable simulation of objects that have been inactive for a period of time.

When the solver sees an object for the first time, it checks whether that object is initially overlapping with any other objects in the simulation and prevents any such pairs of objects from being forced apart. This value is used by the solver to determine whether it has performed this process for the object on a previous frame.
A unique identifier for the object. This value is used by the solver to identify objects that have been added to or removed from the simulation.
that the solver will assign to the next new object that is added.
Determines if the creation frame refers to global Houdini frames (
).  The latter is affected by the offset time and scale time at the DOP network level.

The frame number on which the object will be created. The object is created only when the current frame number is equal to this parameter value. This means the DOP Network must evaluate a timestep at the specified frame, or the object will not be created.
For example, if this value is set to 3.5, the
parameter of the DOP Network must be changed to
to ensure the DOP Network has a timestep at frame
Specifies the initial state of the objects. The

point attributes can be used to vary these values on a per object basis.
        For animated and deforming objects, the
point attribute is used to find the matching point from the
The objects will be simulated and react to other objects in the simulation.
The objects will not move or react to other objects in the simulation.
The objects' transforms will be updated on each timestep from the
, but the objects will not react to other objects in the simulation.
The objects' collision shapes will be rebuilt on each timestep from the
, but the objects will not react to other objects in the simulation.
The objects will be simulated and react to other objects in the simulation, and their collision shapes will also be rebuilt on each timestep from the
Specifies the source of the objects' geometry.
Use the SOP specified by the
Use the SOP connected to the DOP network’s first input.
Use the SOP connected to the DOP network’s second input.
Use the SOP connected to the DOP network’s third input.
Use the SOP connected to the DOP network’s fourth input.
The path to a SOP (or an Object, in which case the display SOP is used) which will be the geometry for this object.
When enabled, specifies a list of point attributes that will be updated on each frame from the
point attribute is used to find the matching point from the SOP geometry.
The transform of the object containing the chosen SOP is applied to the geometry. This is useful if the initial location of the geometry is defined by an object transform.
Controls if the geometry is displayed in the viewport.  Does not reset the simulation when it is changed.
The objects' geometry is displayed in the viewport.

parameter is transformed to match the simulation geometry and is displayed in the viewport.
            This is useful for visualizing the results of the simulation when using lower resolution shapes for the simulation geometry.
Specifies the SOP geometry to use when
Initial position in world space of the object.
Initial orientation of the object. This is in RX/RY/RZ format.

Initial angular velocity of the object. This is the axis of rotation times the rate of rotation. Speed of rotation is measured in degrees per second, so a value of 360 will cause
            the object to rotate once per second.
point attributes of the source geometry will override the object’s initial velocity.
When turned on, displays a visualization of the object’s collision shape, including the

. This is useful for debugging issues with
    collision detection, but is typically slower than only displaying the object’s geometry.
The color of the guide geometry.
The color of the guide geometry if the object is not moving and has been deactivated by the
The shape used by the Bullet engine to represent the object. The
parameter can be used to visualize this collision shape.
The default shape for the object. The
creates a collision shape from the convex hull of the geometry points.

converts the geometry to polygons and creates a concave collision shape from the resulting triangles.
        This shape is useful when simulating concave objects such as a torus or a hollow tube. However, it is recommended to only use the concave representation when necessary, since the convex hull representation typically provides better performance.
The bounding box of the object.
The bounding capsule of the object.
The bounding cylinder of the object.
Creates a complex shape consisting of Bullet primitives (including boxes, spheres, and cylinders). You will need to use the
The bounding sphere of the object.
Create Convex Hull per Set of Connected Primitives
creates a compound shape that contains a separate convex hull collision shape for each set of connected primitives in the geometry.
AutoFit Primitive Boxes, Capsules, Cylinders, Spheres, or Planes to Geometry
When turned on, the object’s Geometry subdata is analyzed instead of using the
, use the geometry bounds to create the shape.
The position of the object shape in the Bullet world. This parameter is available when
AutoFit Primitive Boxes, Capsules, Cylinders, Spheres, or Planes to Geometry
The orientation of the object shape in the Bullet world. This parameter is available when
AutoFit Primitive Boxes, Capsules, Cylinders, Spheres, or Planes to Geometry
The half extents of the box shape. This parameter is available when
AutoFit Primitive Boxes, Capsules, Cylinders, Spheres, or Planes to Geometry
The radius of the sphere shape. This parameter is available when
AutoFit Primitive Boxes, Capsules, Cylinders, Spheres, or Planes to Geometry
The length of the capsule or cylinder in the Y direction. This parameter is available when
AutoFit Primitive Boxes, Capsules, Cylinders, Spheres, or Planes to Geometry

A padding distance between shapes, which is used by the Bullet engine to improve the reliability and performance of the collision detection. You
    may need to scale this value depending on the scale of your scene. This padding increases the size of the collision shape, so it is recommended to turn on
to prevent the collision shape from growing.
This parameter is not available when
When turned on, shrinks the collision geometry to prevent the
from increasing the effective size of the object.

This can improve the simulation’s performance by preventing initially closely-packed collision shapes from interpenetrating, and also removes the gap between
    objects caused by the
, the radius and/or length of each primitive is reduced by
, each polygon in the representation geometry is shifted inward by
This parameter is not available when
The amount of resizing done by
. By default, this value is equal to the

so that
    the resulting size of the collision shape (including the
) is the same size as the object’s geometry.
This parameter is not available when
When turned on, any impacts that occur during the simulation is recorded in the Impacts or Feedback data. Turning on this option may cause the simulation time and memory usage to increase.
The Impacts and Feedback data are added as subdata on the DOP object. You can see them in the
when there is at least one impact during the timestep.

The Feedback data is essentially the same as the Impacts data, but is used when there is mutual interaction in the DOP network between multiple objects that are being solved by different solvers. For example, for an RBD object and FLIP fluid object to mutually interact, the DOP network runs multiple feedback loops to resolve the interactions, and the Feedback data is used to pass impact data between the solvers.
When turned on, disables simulation of a non-moving object until the object moves again. The linear and angular speed thresholds are used to determine whether the object is non-moving. If
is turned off, you will see the color of the guide geometry change from the
The sleeping threshold for the object’s linear velocity. If the object’s linear speed is below this threshold for a period of time, the object may be treated as non-moving.
The sleeping threshold for the object’s angular velocity. If the object’s angular speed is below this threshold for a period of time, the object may be treated as non-moving.

When the solver sees an object for the first time, it checks whether that object is initially overlapping with any other objects in the simulation and prevents any such pairs of objects from being forced apart.
        If this is disabled, initially overlapping objects will be moved apart to resolve the collisions.
To resolve collisions between initially overlapping objects without adding velocity, ensure that

The minimum impulse from a collision that will cause the object to switch from inactive to active. The activation occurs at the instant that the collision occurs.
        The
attribute can be used to prevent the object from being activated by collisions with particular objects.
Specifies that the object’s center of mass should be computed automatically from its collision shape on the next frame it is solved.
Sets the center of mass to the primitive’s initial point position.
Specifies the object’s center of mass.
Determines if the mass will be calculated automatically from the object’s volumetric representation and glued sub-objects.
The mass of an object is its volume times its density.
The absolute mass of the object.
When an object receives a glancing blow, it will often acquire a spin. The amount of spin acquired depends on the shape and mass distribution of the object, known as the
is a scale factor applied to this. A higher stiffness will make the object less liable to spinning, a lower value will make it more ready to spin.
The elasticity of the object. If two objects of bounce 1.0 collide, they rebound without losing energy. If two objects of bounce 0.0 collide, they come to a standstill.

The tangential elasticity of the object. If two objects of bounce forward 1.0 collide, their tangential motion is affected only by friction. If two objects of bounce forward 0.0 collide, their tangential motion is matched.
The coefficient of friction for the object. A value of 0 means the object is frictionless.
This governs how much the tangential velocity is affected by collisions and resting contacts.
An object sliding may have a lower friction coefficient than an object at rest. This is the scale factor that relates the two. It is not a friction coefficient, but a scale between zero and one.
A value of one means that dynamic friction is equal to static friction. A scale of zero means that as soon as static friction is overcome, the object acts without friction.
Temperature marks how warm or cool an object is.  This is used in gas simulations for ignition points of fuel or for buoyancy computations.
Since this does not relate directly to any real world temperature scale, ambient temperature is usually considered 0.
The RBD object created by this node is sent through the single output.
The simulation time for which the node is being evaluated.
Depending on the settings of the

parameters, 
    this value may not be equal to the current Houdini time
    represented by the variable T.

ST is guaranteed to have a value of zero at the
    start of a simulation, so when testing for the first timestep of a
    simulation, it is best to use a test like

The simulation frame (or more accurately, the 
    simulation time step number) for which the node is being evaluated.
Depending on the settings of the

parameters, 
    this value may not be equal to the current Houdini frame number
    represented by the variable F. Instead, it is equal to
    the simulation time (ST) divided by the simulation timestep size 
    (TIMESTEP).

The size of a simulation timestep. This value is
    useful for scaling values that are expressed in units per second, but
    are applied on each timestep.

The inverse of the TIMESTEP value. It is the number
    of timesteps per second of simulation time.

The number of objects in the simulation. For nodes that
    create objects such as the

,
    SNOBJ increases for each object that is evaluated.

A good way to guarantee unique object names is to use an expression
    like

The number of objects that are evaluated by the
    current node during this timestep. This value is often 
    different from SNOBJ, as many nodes do not process all the objects
    in a simulation.

NOBJ may return 0 if the node does not
    process each object sequentially (such as the

The index of the specific object being processed by
    the node. This value always runs from zero to NOBJ-1 in a given
    timestep. It does not identify the current object within the
    simulation like OBJID or OBJNAME; it only identifies the object’s 
    position in the current order of processing.

This value is useful for generating a
    random number for each object, or simply splitting the objects into
    two or more groups to be processed in different ways. This value
    is -1 if the node does not process objects sequentially (such
    as the

The unique identifier for the object being
    processed. Every object is assigned an integer value that is unique
    among all objects in the simulation for all time. Even if an object
    is deleted, its identifier is never reused. This is very useful in
    situations where each object needs to be treated differently, for 
    example, to produce a unique random number for each object.
This value is also the best way to look up information on an object using the dopfield expression function.

OBJID is -1 if the node does not process objects
    sequentially (such as the

This string contains a space-separated list of the unique object
    identifiers for every object being processed by the current node.

This string contains a space-separated list of the names of every
    object being processed by the current node.

The simulation time (see variable ST) at which the
    current object was created.

To check if an object was created
    on the current timestep, the expression

This value is zero if the node does not process
    objects sequentially (such as the

The simulation frame (see variable SF) at which the 
    current object was created. It is equivalent to using the 
    dopsttoframe expression on the OBJCT variable.

This value is zero if the node does not process objects 
    sequentially (such as the

A string value containing the name of the object being
    processed.

Object names are not guaranteed to be unique within a
    simulation. However, if you name your objects carefully so that they
    are unique, the object name can be a much easier way to identify an
    object than the unique object identifier, OBJID.

The object name can
    also be used to treat a number of similar objects (with the same
    name) as a virtual group. If there are 20 objects named

in the activation field
    of a DOP will cause that DOP to operate on only those 20 objects.

This value is the empty string if the node does not process objects
    sequentially (such as the

A string value containing the full path of the current DOP
    network. This value is most useful in DOP subnet digital assets
    where you want to know the path to the DOP network that contains the
    node.

Most dynamics nodes have local variables with the same names as the
    node’s parameters. For example, in a
…to make the object move 0.1 units along the X axis at each timestep.

title: RBD Packed Object
summary: Creates a single DOP object from SOP Geometry that represents a number of RBD Objects.
